importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Lebanese authorities arrested Hannibal Gaddafi in 2015, marking the start of his pre-trial detention related to the disappearance of Musa al-Sadr.

Libyan authorities formally requested Lebanon release Hannibal Gaddafi due to his deteriorating health after a hunger strike, citing the potential for uncovering the truth about al-Sadr’s disappearance.
The Lebanese court ruled on October 18, 2025, ordering the release of Hannibal Gaddafi on $11 million bail, sparking international and domestic reactions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2015 to 2025 marks the duration of Hannibal Gaddafi’s pre-trial detention in Lebanon, during which the case of Musa al-Sadr’s disappearance has remained a persistent political and public issue.

keyTakeAways: Hannibal Gaddafi, son of Muammar Gaddafi, was released on $11 million bail by a Lebanese court in October 2025 after nearly a decade of pre-trial detention.
The arrest and detention of Hannibal Gaddafi is tied to allegations of withholding information about the 1978 disappearance of Musa al-Sadr, a revered Lebanese Shia leader.
The case has long been controversial, with critics, including Human Rights Watch, accusing Lebanon of wrongful imprisonment based on unsubstantiated claims.
Libyan authorities have repeatedly urged Lebanon to release Gaddafi, citing his health deterioration and the potential for uncovering the truth about al-Sadr’s fate.
The al-Sadr family emphasized that their concern is not Gaddafi’s release but rather the unresolved mystery of al-Sadr’s disappearance.
Hannibal Gaddafi’s lawyer, Laurent Bayon, contested the bail, citing international sanctions and financial impossibility of paying $11 million.
The case remains politically sensitive due to historical ties between Libya and Lebanon, especially regarding al-Sadr’s visit and subsequent disappearance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a significant development, a Lebanese court has ordered the release of Hannibal Gaddafi, the son of former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi, on a $11 million bail after nearly a decade of pre-trial detention. The detention stems from allegations that he withheld information about the 1978 disappearance of revered Lebanese Shia leader Musa al-Sadr during a visit to Libya. Despite claims from his lawyer Laurent Bayon that the bail is unreasonable and unfeasible due to international sanctions and financial constraints, the decision has drawn criticism and protests from the al-Sadr family, who emphasize their focus on uncovering the truth about al-Sadr’s fate. Libyan authorities have previously urged Lebanon to release Gaddafi due to his health and the potential for new information about the disappearance. Human Rights Watch has also criticized the detention as unjust. The case remains a highly sensitive political and historical issue, reflecting deep-rooted tensions between Lebanon and Libya over unresolved state secrets and national security concerns.
title: Lebanon court orders son of late Libyan leader Gaddafi freed on $11m bail
